heading: aol profits quadruple
subheading: hot on the heels of smokin' earnings from amazon and ebay, aol reports some big numbers all its own. to celebrate, it will split its stock.
author: wired news report
text: america online said wednesday that record growth in membership, advertising, and e-commerce revenues helped profits more than quadruple in its fiscal second quarter, handily topping wall street estimates. separately, the company announced a two-for-one stock split effective 22 february for shareholders of record as of 8 february.after markets closed, the blue-chip net company reported net income of us$88 million, or 17 cents per share, for the quarter ended 31 december, compared with $20 million, or 4 cents per share a year earlier.wall street expected aol (aol) to make 14 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by first call.revenues for the quarter jumped 62 percent to $960 million, compared with $592 million a year ago. subscription revenue, at $779 million, continued to account for the lion's share of the total, but advertising and e-commerce revenue more than doubled to $126 million."it's obviously an extraordinary quarter for us on every front," said ceo steve case.aol added 1.6 million new members during the quarter, bringing its total to more than 17 million, including its compuserve subsidiary.financial details of aol's pending acquisition of netscape communications weren't included in the quarter. that deal is expected to close in early spring.
